conclusion: Principles of light and shadow formation affect shadow position and size.
Four objects casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D on the ground.
Shadows are cast due to a light source positioned above the objects.
Lowering the light source makes it closer to the objects.
Closer light source changes the angle at which light rays hit the objects.
Shadows become larger as the light source moves closer to the objects.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will increase in size.
Lowering the light source changes the direction of light rays, altering shadow position.
Shadows move outward from the base of the objects, away from the light source.
Shadows extend further from the objects due to more horizontal light rays.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will become larger and move outward on the ground.
